ggplot2.comment_text:
Closing this pull request because I just made these changes myself!  Great minds think alike ;)
I'll push my changes shortly.  I just completed a big re-write of roxygen over the weekend that adds a few new features to reduce documentation duplication.  It's temporarily available at https://github.com/hadley/rxygn but it will be merged back into the main development trunk https://github.com/klutometis/roxygen and hopefully hence to CRAN soon after.
Doh, that was a dumb mistake.  Thanks for the fix!
I would appreciate being told how I should have done this to not create a second issue (I wanted it to be part of #206).
The Rd files are automatically generated from roxygen comments in R - would you mind fixing in the source document? (position-jitter.R)

lubridate.comment_text:
Hi folks. I wonder when this could be merged? I was living with
the impression that it was already merged long ago.
It is good to merge fast in general because more people are testing dev changes and it is
good to merge when the author of the patch has a clear memory of the change. I
already started forgetting what I was doing here.
Vitoshka, can you tell me more about what this is? Thanks.

Well, it does several things because it builds on other pulls. Unfortunately it
doesn't have the best comit history but I assure you that the end code is
clean. I would like to keep the history as it is because of the major input that Ian had in the development of these features. You can diff with master to have a better picture of what is going on.
First it solves the issue #178 which has a long thread associated to it. In a
nutshell the tz argument when date is in ISO-8601 format is not treated
consistently:
ymd_hms("2012-03-04T05:06:07Z",  tz = "America/Chicago")
Date in ISO8601 format; converted timezone from UTC to "America/Chicago".
[1] "2012-03-03 23:06:07 CST"

See the last test case in test-parsers.R.
Second part builds on Ian's implementation of stamps for ISO-8601. See the
tests. In a nutshell all of the following now work correctly:
stamp_Ou <- stamp("2013-01-01T06:00:00Z")
stamp_Oo <- stamp("2013-01-01T00:00:00-06")
stamp_Oz <- stamp("2013-01-01T00:00:00-0600")
stamp_OO <- stamp("2013-01-01T00:00:00-06:00")

See new test cases in tests-stamp.R.
In addition there are quite a number of aesthetic cleanups and new comments of
the code to assure that whenever I come back to my own code I recall fast what
it was about.

typo: I ment to write that ISO8601 is now treated consistently, in the sense
that, when tz is present, ISO8601 time zone is respected and conversion is made
to user specified tz with a warning.

Sorry, I missed this pull somehow.
Could we find a better name for "shift" ?  It's not imidiately clear which direction it shifts. For instance are shifts of -2 and 10 equivalent?
Would we be better off with year_start parameter instead? You pass 10 or "November" and get the same result?

stringr.comment_text:
The function is already available in the most recent stringr:
> c('ac', 'bc', 'ab') %>% str_subset('^a')
[1] "ac" "ab"
Uhm ... didn't notice that. My bad ... Thanks. :)
How about naming it squish as it is called in e.g. ruby :)
Sure... just a suggestion ;) not my pkg
Changed to str_squish as the name makes sense
